messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba layers
messages.msgSnippet: ... Yes.  Also Nishigaki motifs were widely copied by others. Jim [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
messages.messageBody:
>Being at the office, how long did the
>Nishigaki smith go on ?, I assume to the end of the edo period ?.

>Rich

Yes. Also Nishigaki motifs were widely copied by others.

Jim



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba layers
messages.msgSnippet: Cheers Jim, a good lesson there to remember. I will take a better look at the rest of the guard. Being at the office, how long did the Nishigaki smith go on ?,
messages.messageBody:
Cheers Jim, a good lesson there to remember. I will take a better look
at the rest of the guard. Being at the office, how long did the
Nishigaki smith go on ?, I assume to the end of the edo period ?.

Rich

Jim Gilbert wrote:

> Rich,
> What you're seeing inside the nakago ana appears to be the result of
> the hammering to change the size of the nakago ana. That's fairly
> common. Always try to confirm any "layering" in the other sukashi
> openings and rim. This iron looks quite homogeneous in the other
> openings in the photos.
>
> Shodai Nishigaki Kanshiro can indeed show some loose laminations in
> his plate that can be visible in the sukashi or even as delaminations
> on the surface. I can't think of any other Higo makers that have
> that. Your guard is in Nishigaki style, but is pretty late. "Kodai
> Higo."
>
>
> Jim
>


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba layers
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, What you re seeing inside the nakago ana appears to be the result of the hammering to change the size of the nakago ana.  That s fairly common.  Always
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
What you're seeing inside the nakago ana appears to be the result of the hammering to change the size of the nakago ana. That's fairly common. Always try to confirm any "layering" in the other sukashi openings and rim. This iron looks quite homogeneous in the other openings in the photos.

Shodai Nishigaki Kanshiro can indeed show some loose laminations in his plate that can be visible in the sukashi or even as delaminations on the surface. I can't think of any other Higo makers that have that. Your guard is in Nishigaki style, but is pretty late. "Kodai Higo."


Jim



All, are tsuba layers common in Higo, specifically Nishigaki tsuba. I
have been researching this tsuba and the layers are clearly visible in
the nakago-ana yet I have not found much mention of this phenomenon in
any of my books.

nakago-ana
http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/pics/tsuba/Nishigaki-Paluwonia-nakago-.jpg

tsuba
http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/pics/tsuba/Nishigaki-Wisteria-front.jpg

regards

Rich



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: tsuba layers
messages.msgSnippet: All, are tsuba layers common in Higo, specifically Nishigaki tsuba. I have been researching this tsuba and the layers are clearly visible in the nakago-ana yet
messages.messageBody:
All, are tsuba layers common in Higo, specifically Nishigaki tsuba. I
have been researching this tsuba and the layers are clearly visible in
the nakago-ana yet I have not found much mention of this phenomenon in
any of my books.

nakago-ana
http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/pics/tsuba/Nishigaki-Paluwonia-nakago-.jpg

tsuba
http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/pics/tsuba/Nishigaki-Wisteria-front.jpg

regards

Rich

messages.subject: Re: tsuba, waxing, etc...
messages.msgSnippet: Richard, Great information.  Thanks so much for your time and trouble.  I would be (even more) indebted to you if you might be able to direct me to a
messages.messageBody:
Richard,

Great information. Thanks so much for your time and trouble. I
would be (even more) indebted to you if you might be able to
direct me to a site/webpage/publication/collection of photos
which might actually illustrated such primped or doctored tsuba.
I hear all that you're saying, but it would help so much to be able
to actually see pieces which you and others would have such
suspicions about... I really appreciate your help.

Steve



--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Richard George <
rkg@t...> wrote:
> steven,
>
> First of all, even papered pieces may have stuff that might
need to be
> taken care of on
> them (red rust, etc.), and I'd guess even some of these end up
getting
> "primped"
> by later owners. Sorry - Papers are a good start, but...
>
> I had alluded to Jim's article about tsuba care - he
recommends boiling
> water, which works
> pretty well.
>
> On paint, I should have been more clear (that's what I get for
typing
> late at night) - often older
> tsubas were lacquered - remmnants of old paint on a tsuba
should be
> handled with the greatest
> care/respect (on really old tsuba you'll see the paint form this
> funky/cool amalgum with the surface
> patina) - you have to proceed carefully (or just leave well
enough
> alone) when you have old
> paint like that - I had a tosho once I nicknamed "rusty crusty"
because
> there was a fairly thick
> uncared for patina on it - BUT there was also a fair amount of
what
> appeared to be original
> lacquer, so I left it well enough alone - while the tsuba would
probably
> have looked a whole
> lot better/sold for more if I had just attacked it a little with the
> ivory/rubbing, it didn't seem
> right since it would have nuked the lacquer as well... The real
answer
> is experience... You need
> to go and look at and study (and take good pictures of if you're
> motivated) a bunch of good tsuba...
>
> On "primped" tsuba, an amazing number of tsuba in the US
appear to have
> gotten the "treatment" -
> I've pretty much stopped buying pieces from people in the US
who I don't
> know because of this -
> I've been burned enough so I can usually recognize its been
jacked with,
> but I get tired of sending
> pieces back - but you'll even get stuff from Japan occasionally
that has
> been "helped"... (comments
> about how many people don't seem to understand white
balance on digital
> cameras deleted).
>
> Gotta run,
>
> rkg
> (Richard George)
>
> >Hi Richard,
> >
> >Thank you for your excellent words of wisdom. I think the
> >message I'm getting is: just leave well enough alone! So I
> >believe I will... :o).
> >One thing, though: for rookies like me, how would you
suggest
> >being able to spot the oiled, waxed, or (gulp) painted tsuba
that
> >may deceive me? I certainly hear what you're saying, and
want
> >to heed your words. But how, exactly, can I know it when I see
it?
> >I don't believe any of the pieces I've acquired thus far have
been
> >tampered with this way, but I guess I can't really be sure (I
have
> >not attempted any soap and water cleaning of them. They
> >appear in great condition to my untrained eye, and so I
haven't
> >felt any need to clean...). Most of my pieces have Hozon
papers:
> >would this be any indication at all that the tsuba in question
are
> >more likely to be "deception-free"? Or is that entirely
irrelevant?
> >Sorry for all the bothersome questions, but I really am eager
to
> >become informed! Many thanks, Richard, for your time and
> >attention...
> >
> >Steve
> >
> >
> >--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Richard George <
> >rkg@t...> wrote:
> >
> >
> >>steven,
> >>
> >>first,
> >>
> >>DON"T MESS WITH THE RUST INSIDE THE SUKASHI
> >>
> >>
> >CUTOUTS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
> >
> >
> >>Now that I've said that...
> >>
> >>I've seen all sorts of tsuba abuse ("brown" wax, various
> >>
> >>
> >attempts at
> >
> >
> >>repatination, people who have
> >>decided they can do a better job of patination than the
original
> >>
> >>
> >maker
> >
> >
> >>and strip top quality
> >>pieces down and start over, people who just wax them with
> >>
> >>
> >some magic
> >
> >
> >>compound, oil them, etc.,.) - don't do it -
> >>basically, Jinsoo is absolutely correct - if the surface patina
is
> >>
> >>
> >good,
> >
> >
> >>just store 'em somewhere where they
> >>won't get condensed on and rub them periodically with your
> >>
> >>
> >hands/a soft
> >
> >
> >>cloth. If its got problems, see below...
> >>
> >>the deadly enemy of iron tsuba is red rust - if your piece has
> >>
> >>
> >this on
> >
> >
> >>it, its a problem. somehow you have to
> >>get this off - some people use horn, but I've found that ivory
> >>
> >>
> >seems to
> >
> >
> >>be really good for use to scrape this off
> >>while not harming the the brown rust (I think Jim Gilbert has
an
> >>excellent article on this in a couple of
> >>places on line...). - often you have to work at it quite a bit - I
> >>sometimes alternate scraping sessions with
> >>washing the piece in warm water with a mild soap and a
soft
> >>toothbrush... And again, you only want to
> >>do this ONLY on the outside surfaces of the tsuba, not down
in
> >>
> >>
> >the sukashi.
> >
> >
> >>After you've done that, the revealed old rust regions are often
> >>
> >>
> >pretty
> >
> >
> >>gnarly, or if the piece is just plain "rough",
> >>you can "pocket polish" the piece - just carry it around
> >>in your pocket for a few weeks (NOT where you carry your
keys/
> >>
> >>
> >change) -
> >
> >
> >>this gives the piece a nice rubbed look that
> >>is hard to get by just marathon rubbing sessions with a
cloth...
> >>
> >>When you're buying tsuba, always be on the lookout for
pieces
> >>
> >>
> >that have
> >
> >
> >>been "primped" like this - you'll see
> >>people that hide a multitude of sins with various waxes, oils,
> >>
> >>
> >PAINT (I
> >
> >
> >>got a couple like this - the guy color
> >>matched the patina and jammed the tsuba (!!) - looked real
> >>
> >>
> >darned good,
> >
> >
> >>too - I was quite happy until I tried to clean
> >>up a rough spot I thought was oil, used some enamel
thinner,
> >>
> >>
> >and -
> >
> >
> >>surprise!...), etc.,. I'd like to think they
> >>just wanted the pieces to look better/didn't know any better
and
> >>
> >>
> >really
> >
> >
> >>weren't thinking fraudulent thoughts, but....
> >>
> >>Good Luck,
> >>
> >>rkg
> >>(Richard George)
> >>
> >>
> >>
> >>>Milt,
> >>>
> >>>Jinsoo Kim told me that the best way to care for the old iron
> >>>sukashi pieces I have is to simply rub them now and then
> >>>
> >>>
> >with a soft
> >
> >
> >>>silk cloth. I have read the various prescriptions for
cleaning,
> >>>waxing, etc... and, as I've mentioned, I am quite the novice
> >>>
> >>>
> >and so
> >
> >
> >>>am in the dark as to what the current thinking on this is.
The
> >>>tsuba I have are all in excellent condition, with only minimal
> >>>
> >>>
> >spots
> >
> >
> >>>of light surface rust in some of the sukashi openings, and
> >>>
> >>>
> >none on
> >
> >
> >>>the plate or rim. Again, I appreciate your thoughts on this,
> >>>
> >>>
> >and am
> >
> >
> >>>gradually coming to a view that if I'm in doubt, do nothing!
> >>>
> >>>Thanks again,
> >>>
> >>>Steve
> >>>
> >>>
> >>>
> >>>
> >>>
> >>>Yahoo! Groups Links
> >>>
> >>>
> >>>
> >>>
> >>>
> >>>
> >>>
> >>>
> >>>
> >>>
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >Yahoo! Groups Links
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
>
>

messages.subject: Re: tsuba, waxing, etc...
messages.msgSnippet: Thanks, Curran.  It is really helping to get all this feedback.  I m hoping that a clear general recommended approach will emerge, and that I can take some
messages.messageBody:
Thanks, Curran. It is really helping to get all this feedback. I'm
hoping that a clear general recommended approach will
emerge, and that I can take some confidence from this. Your
suggestion about finding a $50 tsuba to work on is good.
Incidentally, where does one find the substances (ivory, bone,
etc...) mentioned? Thanks again.

Steve

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Curran Campbell <
neobliviscar@y...> wrote:
> Steve,
>
> -What he said.-
> (I concur).
>
> Read Gilbert article (on his website) on cleaning
> tsuba. If/when you first try to clean a tsuba, go
> slow. I overdid one of my first ones a bit, and have
> spent 2 years promoting healthy repatination & the
> occassional rub. On a good dense Tosho tsuba, this is
> an agonizingly slow process. Many people don't have
> the patience.
> When doing the horn/ivory cleaning, but to practice
> with a $50 tsuba off ebay that has just a little rust.
> It will get you accustomed to the feel of doint the
> work.
>
> Curran
>
> >
> > steven,
> >
> > first,
> >
> > DON"T MESS WITH THE RUST INSIDE THE SUKASHI
> > CUTOUTS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
> >
> > Now that I've said that...
> >
> > I've seen all sorts of tsuba abuse ("brown" wax,
> > various attempts at
> > repatination, people who have
> > decided they can do a better job of patination than
> > the original maker
> > and strip top quality
> > pieces down and start over, people who just wax them
> > with some magic
> > compound, oil them, etc.,.) - don't do it -
> > basically, Jinsoo is absolutely correct - if the
> > surface patina is good,
> > just store 'em somewhere where they
> > won't get condensed on and rub them periodically
> > with your hands/a soft
> > cloth. If its got problems, see below...
> >
> > the deadly enemy of iron tsuba is red rust - if your
> > piece has this on
> > it, its a problem. somehow you have to
> > get this off - some people use horn, but I've found
> > that ivory seems to
> > be really good for use to scrape this off
> > while not harming the the brown rust (I think Jim
> > Gilbert has an
> > excellent article on this in a couple of
> > places on line...). - often you have to work at it
> > quite a bit - I
> > sometimes alternate scraping sessions with
> > washing the piece in warm water with a mild soap and
> > a soft
> > toothbrush... And again, you only want to
> > do this ONLY on the outside surfaces of the tsuba,
> > not down in the sukashi.
> >
> > After you've done that, the revealed old rust
> > regions are often pretty
> > gnarly, or if the piece is just plain "rough",
> > you can "pocket polish" the piece - just carry it
> > around
> > in your pocket for a few weeks (NOT where you carry
> > your keys/change) -
> > this gives the piece a nice rubbed look that
> > is hard to get by just marathon rubbing sessions
> > with a cloth...
> >
> > When you're buying tsuba, always be on the lookout
> > for pieces that have
> > been "primped" like this - you'll see
> > people that hide a multitude of sins with various
> > waxes, oils, PAINT (I
> > got a couple like this - the guy color
> > matched the patina and jammed the tsuba (!!) -
> > looked real darned good,
> > too - I was quite happy until I tried to clean
> > up a rough spot I thought was oil, used some enamel
> > thinner, and -
> > surprise!...), etc.,. I'd like to think they
> > just wanted the pieces to look better/didn't know
> > any better and really
> > weren't thinking fraudulent thoughts, but....
> >
> > Good Luck,
> >
> > rkg
> > (Richard George)
> >
> > >Milt,
> > >
> > >Jinsoo Kim told me that the best way to care for
> > the old iron
> > >sukashi pieces I have is to simply rub them now and
> > then with a soft
> > >silk cloth. I have read the various prescriptions
> > for cleaning,
> > >waxing, etc... and, as I've mentioned, I am quite
> > the novice and so
> > >am in the dark as to what the current thinking on
> > this is. The
> > >tsuba I have are all in excellent condition, with
> > only minimal spots
> > >of light surface rust in some of the sukashi
> > openings, and none on
> > >the plate or rim. Again, I appreciate your
> > thoughts on this, and am
> > >gradually coming to a view that if I'm in doubt, do
> > nothing!
> > >
> > >Thanks again,
> > >
> > >Steve
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >Yahoo! Groups Links
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >
> >
> >
> >
> >
>
>
>
>
> __________________________________
> Do you Yahoo!?

> http://promotions.yahoo.com/new_mail

messages.subject: Re: tsuba, waxing, etc...
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Kirk, Yes, it does help. Thanks.  All this information you and the others are providing is very useful.  As it happens, none of the tsuba I have is in
messages.messageBody:
Hi Kirk,

Yes, it does help. Thanks. All this information you and the others
are providing is very useful. As it happens, none of the tsuba I
have is in "dirty" condition, so there is really nothing to tempt me
to try cleaning in any form, except, perhaps, the occasional light
rubbing with the soft cloth. I hear what you're saying even here,
however, so I will err on the side of caution, as you say. Thanks,
too, for your insight re: the Hozon papers question. I appreciate
it!

Steve


--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "frkirk" <frkirk@y...>
wrote:
> Hi Steven and All
> I am fairly new to the group but throught I would throw my 2
cents
> in.
> On the latter part of your question- if a tsuba has Hozon (or
other
> respected) papers I woud leave it be- even be cautious about
how
> much you "pocket polish" it. I have also heard tell of great
tsubas
> that were made too glossy my over zealous cloth rubbers. As
you
> say, leave well enough alone and err on the side of caution.
> If the tsuba is un-certified and you are unsure as to the
> authenticity of its patina, I beleive that dunking it in boiling
> water cannot harm it and may remove grime and wax at least.
Please
> use only plain water for this and make sure the piece is dry
ASAP
> once it is removed. What you may get from this process will be
a
> UGLY lookin tsuba since any false patina will be stripped and
red
> rust, pits, etc will be exposed. While you might be saying to
> yourself, "It looked better before" you now can start from
ground
> zero and nurse it back to health.
>
> Hope this helps
> Kirk
>

steven_88_2000@y...>

to

> > attempts at
> > > repatination, people who have
> > > decided they can do a better job of patination than the
original
> > maker
> > > and strip top quality
> > > pieces down and start over, people who just wax them with
> > some magic
> > > compound, oil them, etc.,.) - don't do it -

> is
> > good,
> > > just store 'em somewhere where they
> > > won't get condensed on and rub them periodically with your
> > hands/a soft
> > > cloth. If its got problems, see below...
> > >
> > > the deadly enemy of iron tsuba is red rust - if your piece
has
> > this on
> > > it, its a problem. somehow you have to
> > > get this off - some people use horn, but I've found that ivory
> > seems to
> > > be really good for use to scrape this off
> > > while not harming the the brown rust (I think Jim Gilbert
has an

> I
> > > sometimes alternate scraping sessions with
> > > washing the piece in warm water with a mild soap and a
soft

> > > do this ONLY on the outside surfaces of the tsuba, not
down in
> > the sukashi.
> > >
> > > After you've done that, the revealed old rust regions are
often
> > pretty

> > > you can "pocket polish" the piece - just carry it around
> > > in your pocket for a few weeks (NOT where you carry your
keys/

pieces

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba, waxing, etc...
messages.msgSnippet: Steve, (more of -what he said-). Just nodding my head in agreement at this point. Warning that many initially tsuba look ugly as heck after boiling. Curran ...
messages.messageBody:
Steve,

(more of -what he said-).
Just nodding my head in agreement at this point.
Warning that many initially tsuba look ugly as heck
after boiling.

Curran


--- Richard George <rkg@...> wrote:

> steven,
>
> First of all, even papered pieces may have stuff
> that might need to be
> taken care of on
> them (red rust, etc.), and I'd guess even some of
> these end up getting
> "primped"
> by later owners. Sorry - Papers are a good start,
> but...
>
> I had alluded to Jim's article about tsuba care - he
> recommends boiling
> water, which works
> pretty well.
>
> On paint, I should have been more clear (that's what
> I get for typing
> late at night) - often older
> tsubas were lacquered - remmnants of old paint on a
> tsuba should be
> handled with the greatest
> care/respect (on really old tsuba you'll see the
> paint form this
> funky/cool amalgum with the surface
> patina) - you have to proceed carefully (or just
> leave well enough
> alone) when you have old
> paint like that - I had a tosho once I nicknamed
> "rusty crusty" because
> there was a fairly thick
> uncared for patina on it - BUT there was also a fair
> amount of what
> appeared to be original
> lacquer, so I left it well enough alone - while the
> tsuba would probably
> have looked a whole
> lot better/sold for more if I had just attacked it a
> little with the
> ivory/rubbing, it didn't seem
> right since it would have nuked the lacquer as
> well... The real answer
> is experience... You need
> to go and look at and study (and take good pictures
> of if you're
> motivated) a bunch of good tsuba...
>
> On "primped" tsuba, an amazing number of tsuba in
> the US appear to have
> gotten the "treatment" -
> I've pretty much stopped buying pieces from people
> in the US who I don't
> know because of this -
> I've been burned enough so I can usually recognize
> its been jacked with,
> but I get tired of sending
> pieces back - but you'll even get stuff from Japan
> occasionally that has
> been "helped"... (comments
> about how many people don't seem to understand white
> balance on digital
> cameras deleted).
>
> Gotta run,
>
> rkg
> (Richard George)
>
> >Hi Richard,
> >
> >Thank you for your excellent words of wisdom. I
> think the
> >message I'm getting is: just leave well enough
> alone! So I
> >believe I will... :o).
> >One thing, though: for rookies like me, how would
> you suggest
> >being able to spot the oiled, waxed, or (gulp)
> painted tsuba that
> >may deceive me? I certainly hear what you're
> saying, and want
> >to heed your words. But how, exactly, can I know
> it when I see it?
> >I don't believe any of the pieces I've acquired
> thus far have been
> >tampered with this way, but I guess I can't really
> be sure (I have
> >not attempted any soap and water cleaning of them.
> They
> >appear in great condition to my untrained eye, and
> so I haven't
> >felt any need to clean...). Most of my pieces have
> Hozon papers:
> >would this be any indication at all that the tsuba
> in question are
> >more likely to be "deception-free"? Or is that
> entirely irrelevant?
> >Sorry for all the bothersome questions, but I
> really am eager to
> >become informed! Many thanks, Richard, for your
> time and
> >attention...
> >
> >Steve
> >
> >
> >--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Richard George
> <
> >rkg@t...> wrote:
> >
> >
> >>steven,
> >>
> >>first,
> >>
> >>DON"T MESS WITH THE RUST INSIDE THE SUKASHI
> >>
> >>
> >CUTOUTS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
> >

> >>

> various
> >>

> >>decided they can do a better job of patination
> than the original
> >>

> them with
> >>

> >some magic
> >

> >>compound, oil them, etc.,.) - don't do it -

> surface patina is
> >>

> >good,
> >
> >
> >>just store 'em somewhere where they
> >>won't get condensed on and rub them periodically
> with your
> >>
> >>
> >hands/a soft
> >
> >
> >>cloth. If its got problems, see below...
> >>
> >>the deadly enemy of iron tsuba is red rust - if
> your piece has
> >>

> >this on
> >
> >
> >>it, its a problem. somehow you have to
> >>get this off - some people use horn, but I've
> found that ivory
> >>

> >seems to
> >

> >>be really good for use to scrape this off
> >>while not harming the the brown rust (I think Jim
> Gilbert has an
> >>excellent article on this in a couple of
> >>places on line...). - often you have to work at
> it quite a bit - I
> >>sometimes alternate scraping sessions with
> >>washing the piece in warm water with a mild soap
> and a soft
> >>toothbrush... And again, you only want to
> >>do this ONLY on the outside surfaces of the tsuba,
> not down in
> >>
> >>
> >the sukashi.
> >
> >
> >>After you've done that, the revealed old rust
> regions are often
> >>
> >>
> >pretty
> >
> >
> >>gnarly, or if the piece is just plain "rough",
> >>you can "pocket polish" the piece - just carry it
> around
> >>in your pocket for a few weeks (NOT where you
> carry your keys/
> >>
> >>
> >change) -
> >
> >
> >>this gives the piece a nice rubbed look that
> >>is hard to get by just marathon rubbing sessions
> with a cloth...
> >>
> >>When you're buying tsuba, always be on the lookout
> for pieces
> >>
> >>

> >
> >
> >>been "primped" like this - you'll see
> >>people that hide a multitude of sins with various
> waxes, oils,
> >>

> >PAINT (I
> >

> >>got a couple like this - the guy color
> >>matched the patina and jammed the tsuba (!!) -
> looked real
> >>

> enamel thinner,

> >>

> >

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba, waxing, etc...
messages.msgSnippet: Steve, -What he said.- (I concur). Read Gilbert article (on his website) on cleaning tsuba. If/when you first try to clean a tsuba, go slow. I overdid one of
messages.messageBody:
Steve,

-What he said.-
(I concur).

Read Gilbert article (on his website) on cleaning
tsuba. If/when you first try to clean a tsuba, go
slow. I overdid one of my first ones a bit, and have
spent 2 years promoting healthy repatination & the
occassional rub. On a good dense Tosho tsuba, this is
an agonizingly slow process. Many people don't have
the patience.
When doing the horn/ivory cleaning, but to practice
with a $50 tsuba off ebay that has just a little rust.
It will get you accustomed to the feel of doint the
work.

Curran

>
> steven,
>
> first,
>
> DON"T MESS WITH THE RUST INSIDE THE SUKASHI
> CUTOUTS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
>
> Now that I've said that...
>
> I've seen all sorts of tsuba abuse ("brown" wax,
> various attempts at
> repatination, people who have
> decided they can do a better job of patination than
> the original maker
> and strip top quality
> pieces down and start over, people who just wax them
> with some magic
> compound, oil them, etc.,.) - don't do it -
> basically, Jinsoo is absolutely correct - if the
> surface patina is good,
> just store 'em somewhere where they
> won't get condensed on and rub them periodically
> with your hands/a soft
> cloth. If its got problems, see below...
>
> the deadly enemy of iron tsuba is red rust - if your
> piece has this on
> it, its a problem. somehow you have to
> get this off - some people use horn, but I've found
> that ivory seems to
> be really good for use to scrape this off
> while not harming the the brown rust (I think Jim
> Gilbert has an
> excellent article on this in a couple of
> places on line...). - often you have to work at it
> quite a bit - I
> sometimes alternate scraping sessions with
> washing the piece in warm water with a mild soap and
> a soft
> toothbrush... And again, you only want to
> do this ONLY on the outside surfaces of the tsuba,
> not down in the sukashi.
>
> After you've done that, the revealed old rust
> regions are often pretty
> gnarly, or if the piece is just plain "rough",
> you can "pocket polish" the piece - just carry it
> around
> in your pocket for a few weeks (NOT where you carry
> your keys/change) -
> this gives the piece a nice rubbed look that
> is hard to get by just marathon rubbing sessions
> with a cloth...
>
> When you're buying tsuba, always be on the lookout
> for pieces that have
> been "primped" like this - you'll see
> people that hide a multitude of sins with various
> waxes, oils, PAINT (I
> got a couple like this - the guy color
> matched the patina and jammed the tsuba (!!) -
> looked real darned good,
> too - I was quite happy until I tried to clean
> up a rough spot I thought was oil, used some enamel
> thinner, and -
> surprise!...), etc.,. I'd like to think they
> just wanted the pieces to look better/didn't know
> any better and really
> weren't thinking fraudulent thoughts, but....
>
> Good Luck,
>
> rkg
> (Richard George)
>
> >Milt,
> >
> >Jinsoo Kim told me that the best way to care for
> the old iron
> >sukashi pieces I have is to simply rub them now and
> then with a soft
> >silk cloth. I have read the various prescriptions
> for cleaning,
> >waxing, etc... and, as I've mentioned, I am quite
> the novice and so
> >am in the dark as to what the current thinking on
> this is. The
> >tsuba I have are all in excellent condition, with
> only minimal spots
> >of light surface rust in some of the sukashi
> openings, and none on
> >the plate or rim. Again, I appreciate your
> thoughts on this, and am
> >gradually coming to a view that if I'm in doubt, do
> nothing!
> >
> >Thanks again,
> >
> >Steve
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >Yahoo! Groups Links
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
>
>
>
>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba, waxing, etc...
messages.msgSnippet: steven, First of all, even papered pieces may have stuff that might need to be taken care of on them (red rust, etc.), and I d guess even some of these end up
messages.messageBody:
steven,

First of all, even papered pieces may have stuff that might need to be
taken care of on
them (red rust, etc.), and I'd guess even some of these end up getting
"primped"
by later owners. Sorry - Papers are a good start, but...

I had alluded to Jim's article about tsuba care - he recommends boiling
water, which works
pretty well.

On paint, I should have been more clear (that's what I get for typing
late at night) - often older
tsubas were lacquered - remmnants of old paint on a tsuba should be
handled with the greatest
care/respect (on really old tsuba you'll see the paint form this
funky/cool amalgum with the surface
patina) - you have to proceed carefully (or just leave well enough
alone) when you have old
paint like that - I had a tosho once I nicknamed "rusty crusty" because
there was a fairly thick
uncared for patina on it - BUT there was also a fair amount of what
appeared to be original
lacquer, so I left it well enough alone - while the tsuba would probably
have looked a whole
lot better/sold for more if I had just attacked it a little with the
ivory/rubbing, it didn't seem
right since it would have nuked the lacquer as well... The real answer
is experience... You need
to go and look at and study (and take good pictures of if you're
motivated) a bunch of good tsuba...

On "primped" tsuba, an amazing number of tsuba in the US appear to have
gotten the "treatment" -
I've pretty much stopped buying pieces from people in the US who I don't
know because of this -
I've been burned enough so I can usually recognize its been jacked with,
but I get tired of sending
pieces back - but you'll even get stuff from Japan occasionally that has
been "helped"... (comments
about how many people don't seem to understand white balance on digital
cameras deleted).

Gotta run,

rkg
(Richard George)

>Hi Richard,
>
>Thank you for your excellent words of wisdom. I think the
>message I'm getting is: just leave well enough alone! So I
>believe I will... :o).
>One thing, though: for rookies like me, how would you suggest
>being able to spot the oiled, waxed, or (gulp) painted tsuba that
>may deceive me? I certainly hear what you're saying, and want
>to heed your words. But how, exactly, can I know it when I see it?
>I don't believe any of the pieces I've acquired thus far have been
>tampered with this way, but I guess I can't really be sure (I have
>not attempted any soap and water cleaning of them. They
>appear in great condition to my untrained eye, and so I haven't
>felt any need to clean...). Most of my pieces have Hozon papers:
>would this be any indication at all that the tsuba in question are
>more likely to be "deception-free"? Or is that entirely irrelevant?
>Sorry for all the bothersome questions, but I really am eager to
>become informed! Many thanks, Richard, for your time and
>attention...
>
>Steve
>
>
>--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Richard George <
>rkg@t...> wrote:
>
>
>>steven,
>>
>>first,
>>
>>DON"T MESS WITH THE RUST INSIDE THE SUKASHI
>>
>>
>CUTOUTS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
>
>

>>

>>

>

>>decided they can do a better job of patination than the original
>>

>>

>>washing the piece in warm water with a mild soap and a soft

messages.subject: Re: tsuba, waxing, etc...
messages.msgSnippet: 1. look at tsuba under different lighting condition.........I found spoting hidden red rust best under direct sunlight . 2. Use your nose like a dog , smell
messages.messageBody:
1. look at tsuba under different lighting condition.........I found
spoting hidden red rust best under direct sunlight .
2. Use your nose like a dog , smell them !!


well, there are ways to restore tsuba. Cary and most other dealers
have their restoration people . So restoration is NOT a cardinal
sin , that is, assuming you know what you are doing.
If you really want to try your hands on restoration, buy some po-edo
( an e-bay seller well known for selling cheapo )tsuba, they are
cheap and they lack " artistic merits ".

By the way, I don't think there's any school in training tsuba
restorers. If they charge you a fee.....they are professional. If
you do it yourself, it's amateur. Hahhahaaaaa, flame on, I am ready
for ye...


milt

messages.subject: Re: tsuba, waxing, etc...
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Steven and All I am fairly new to the group but throught I would throw my 2 cents in. On the latter part of your question- if a tsuba has Hozon (or other
messages.messageBody:
Hi Steven and All
I am fairly new to the group but throught I would throw my 2 cents
in.
On the latter part of your question- if a tsuba has Hozon (or other
respected) papers I woud leave it be- even be cautious about how
much you "pocket polish" it. I have also heard tell of great tsubas
that were made too glossy my over zealous cloth rubbers. As you
say, leave well enough alone and err on the side of caution.
If the tsuba is un-certified and you are unsure as to the
authenticity of its patina, I beleive that dunking it in boiling
water cannot harm it and may remove grime and wax at least. Please
use only plain water for this and make sure the piece is dry ASAP
once it is removed. What you may get from this process will be a
UGLY lookin tsuba since any false patina will be stripped and red
rust, pits, etc will be exposed. While you might be saying to
yourself, "It looked better before" you now can start from ground
zero and nurse it back to health.

Hope this helps
Kirk

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "steven" <steven_88_2000@y...>
wrote:

>
> Thank you for your excellent words of wisdom. I think the

> believe I will... :o).

it?

irrelevant?

messages.subject: Re: tsuba, waxing, etc...
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Richard, Thank you for your excellent words of wisdom.  I think the message I m getting is:  just leave well enough alone!  So I believe I will...  :o). One
messages.messageBody:
Hi Richard,

Thank you for your excellent words of wisdom. I think the
message I'm getting is: just leave well enough alone! So I
believe I will... :o).
One thing, though: for rookies like me, how would you suggest
being able to spot the oiled, waxed, or (gulp) painted tsuba that
may deceive me? I certainly hear what you're saying, and want
to heed your words. But how, exactly, can I know it when I see it?
I don't believe any of the pieces I've acquired thus far have been
tampered with this way, but I guess I can't really be sure (I have
not attempted any soap and water cleaning of them. They
appear in great condition to my untrained eye, and so I haven't
felt any need to clean...). Most of my pieces have Hozon papers:
would this be any indication at all that the tsuba in question are
more likely to be "deception-free"? Or is that entirely irrelevant?
Sorry for all the bothersome questions, but I really am eager to
become informed! Many thanks, Richard, for your time and
attention...

Steve

rkg@t...> wrote:

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba, waxing, etc...
messages.msgSnippet: steven, first, DON T MESS WITH THE RUST INSIDE THE SUKASHI CUTOUTS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Now that I ve said that... I ve seen all sorts of tsuba abuse ( brown wax,
messages.messageBody:
steven,

first,

DON"T MESS WITH THE RUST INSIDE THE SUKASHI CUTOUTS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Now that I've said that...

I've seen all sorts of tsuba abuse ("brown" wax, various attempts at
repatination, people who have
decided they can do a better job of patination than the original maker
and strip top quality
pieces down and start over, people who just wax them with some magic
compound, oil them, etc.,.) - don't do it -
basically, Jinsoo is absolutely correct - if the surface patina is good,
just store 'em somewhere where they
won't get condensed on and rub them periodically with your hands/a soft
cloth. If its got problems, see below...

the deadly enemy of iron tsuba is red rust - if your piece has this on
it, its a problem. somehow you have to
get this off - some people use horn, but I've found that ivory seems to
be really good for use to scrape this off
while not harming the the brown rust (I think Jim Gilbert has an
excellent article on this in a couple of
places on line...). - often you have to work at it quite a bit - I
sometimes alternate scraping sessions with
washing the piece in warm water with a mild soap and a soft
toothbrush... And again, you only want to
do this ONLY on the outside surfaces of the tsuba, not down in the sukashi.

After you've done that, the revealed old rust regions are often pretty
gnarly, or if the piece is just plain "rough",
you can "pocket polish" the piece - just carry it around
in your pocket for a few weeks (NOT where you carry your keys/change) -
this gives the piece a nice rubbed look that
is hard to get by just marathon rubbing sessions with a cloth...

When you're buying tsuba, always be on the lookout for pieces that have
been "primped" like this - you'll see
people that hide a multitude of sins with various waxes, oils, PAINT (I
got a couple like this - the guy color
matched the patina and jammed the tsuba (!!) - looked real darned good,
too - I was quite happy until I tried to clean
up a rough spot I thought was oil, used some enamel thinner, and -
surprise!...), etc.,. I'd like to think they
just wanted the pieces to look better/didn't know any better and really
weren't thinking fraudulent thoughts, but....

Good Luck,

rkg
(Richard George)

>Milt,
>
>Jinsoo Kim told me that the best way to care for the old iron
>sukashi pieces I have is to simply rub them now and then with a soft
>silk cloth. I have read the various prescriptions for cleaning,
>waxing, etc... and, as I've mentioned, I am quite the novice and so
>am in the dark as to what the current thinking on this is. The
>tsuba I have are all in excellent condition, with only minimal spots
>of light surface rust in some of the sukashi openings, and none on
>the plate or rim. Again, I appreciate your thoughts on this, and am
>gradually coming to a view that if I'm in doubt, do nothing!
>
>Thanks again,
>
>Steve
>
>
>
>
>
>Yahoo! Groups Links
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>

messages.subject: tsuba, waxing, etc...
messages.msgSnippet: Milt, Jinsoo Kim told me that the best way to care for the old iron sukashi pieces I have is to simply rub them now and then with a soft silk cloth.  I have
messages.messageBody:
Milt,

Jinsoo Kim told me that the best way to care for the old iron
sukashi pieces I have is to simply rub them now and then with a soft
silk cloth. I have read the various prescriptions for cleaning,
waxing, etc... and, as I've mentioned, I am quite the novice and so
am in the dark as to what the current thinking on this is. The
tsuba I have are all in excellent condition, with only minimal spots
of light surface rust in some of the sukashi openings, and none on
the plate or rim. Again, I appreciate your thoughts on this, and am
gradually coming to a view that if I'm in doubt, do nothing!

Thanks again,

Steve
